articles.headline: Attention Shifts to China for Private Equity Industry
articles.snippet: Global private equity firms are seeking to raise capital from China’s wealthy individuals and institutions, even as the nation works to create a private equity industry of its own.
articles.abstract: Global private equity firms are seeking to raise capital from China’s wealthy individuals and institutions, even as the nation works to create a private equity industry of its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  A few weeks ago, Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman of the Blackstone Group, the world’s biggest private equity firm, signed a joint venture here with Shanghai’s municipal government, creating the first Blackstone fund denominated entirely in Chinese currency.

articles.headline: U.S. Teaches Carmakers Capitalism
articles.snippet: The U.S. takeover of G.M. and Chrysler isn’t an unqualified success, but rising auto prices may be more than a statistical fluke.
articles.abstract: The U.S. takeover of G.M. and Chrysler isn’t an unqualified success, but rising auto prices may be more than a statistical fluke.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the American auto industry was owned by investors, it acted like a government enterprise.

articles.headline: Panel Votes to Broaden Oversight of the Fed
articles.snippet: Rejecting warnings by the Obama administration, a committee approved a plan by Representative Ron Paul to carry out sweeping new audits of the central bank’s policy decisions and operations.
articles.abstract: Rejecting warnings by the Obama administration, a committee approved a plan by Representative Ron Paul to carry out sweeping new audits of the central bank’s policy decisions and operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a display of populist anger toward the Federal Reserve, a House panel voted on Thursday to let Congress carry out sweeping new oversights of the central bank’s policy decisions and operations.

articles.headline: Air Defense Push Inspired by 9/11 Gets a 2nd Look
articles.snippet: The commander of military forces protecting North America has ordered a review of the costly air defenses intended to prevent another Sept. 11-style terrorism attack.
articles.abstract: The commander of military forces protecting North America has ordered a review of the costly air defenses intended to prevent another Sept. 11-style terrorism attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS  The commander of military forces protecting North America has ordered a review of the costly air defenses intended to prevent another Sept. 11-style terrorism attack, an assessment aimed at determining whether the commitment of jet fighters, other aircraft and crews remains justified.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: With F.H.A. Help, Easy Loans in Expensive Areas
articles.snippet: An effort by the F.H.A. to prop up real estate prices amid rising defaults has put taxpayers at risk.
articles.abstract: An effort by the F.H.A. to prop up real estate prices amid rising defaults has put taxpayers at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In January, Mike Rowland was so broke that he had to raid his retirement savings to move here from Boston.

articles.headline: Winfrey Bets on Her Future With Cable
articles.snippet: Oprah Winfrey will end her daytime talk show in 2011 as she prepares to start a cable channel of her own.
articles.abstract: Oprah Winfrey will end her daytime talk show in 2011 as she prepares to start a cable channel of her own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey is giving network television one of her trademark aha moments.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Ohio Sues Rating Firms for Losses in Funds
articles.snippet: Ohio claims state funds lost $457 million because the rating agencies “departed from their objective, neutral role as arbiters.”
articles.abstract: Ohio claims state funds lost $457 million because the rating agencies “departed from their objective, neutral role as arbiters.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Already facing a spate of private lawsuits, the legal troubles of the country’s largest credit rating agencies deepened on Friday when the attorney general of Ohio sued Moody’s Investors Service, Standard & Poor’s and Fitch, claiming that they had cost state retirement and pension funds some $457 million by approving high-risk Wall Street securities that went bust in the financial collapse.
